Fried Chicken
Ingredients
8 skinless boneless chicken thighs
sunflower oil, for deep-frying

For the spice mix
2 tbsp paprika
2 tsp garlic granules
1 tsp chilli powder
1 tsp black pepper
Â½ tsp dried oregano
1 chicken stock cube

For the buttermilk marinade
500ml whole milk
2 tbsp cider or white wine vinegar
1 egg

For the coating
100g self-raising flour
100g cornflour
Â¼ tsp turmeric

Method
STEP 1
To make the spice mix, combine all the ingredients. Whisk the milk with the vinegar, egg, Â½ tsp salt and 1 tbsp spice mix in a bowl or deep plastic container to make the buttermilk marinade. Open the chicken thighs and put between two pieces of baking parchment, then flatten using a rolling pin. Transfer to the marinade, then cover and chill for 4 hrs, or overnight.

STEP 2
Make the coating by combining the flours and turmeric with most of the remaining spice mix (reserving 1 tsp) and a generous pinch of salt. Drain the chicken thighs, reserving the marinade. One by one, dredge each thigh in the flour, then dip in the reserved marinade, then dredge again in the flour, pressing on as much as you can to coat. Transfer the coated thighs to a large plate.

STEP 3
Heat a 10cm depth of oil in a shallow saucepan or deep-fat fryer until it reaches 175C. Lower two or three of the thighs in at a time and fry undisturbed for 3 mins, making sure the temperature doesnâ€™t drop below 160C (it should stay at about 170C). Flip the thighs, then fry for another 2-3 mins until deeply golden and crisp on both sides. Lift the chicken out and transfer to a tray lined with kitchen paper to drain, then put on a rack and keep warm in a low oven while you fry the remaining thighs.

STEP 4
When all the chicken has been fried, combine the reserved spice mix with 1 tbsp flaky sea salt and sprinkle over the chicken to serve.

[b][h1] DON'T WASTE YOUR TIME ON THIS, GO PLAY TEAM FORTRESS 2 [/h1][/b]

Blizzard is a terrible company, ignoring their issues in reality, this game is a money hog. 

A big part of the advertisement for the game was the ability to carry over all your ow1 skins, and all your credits. That was a half-lie, they carried over some skins, only the basic recoloured skins, and they instead substituted ow1 skins for credits to buy the very few they ported in ow2. 

They promised cases would carry over, they instead opened all of them in every account when the game went to shut down, so they had 0 to carry over. Overwatch 2 reintroduced some of the skins, but you have to pay for them now with more real life money. 

The only benefit over the original game is it feels slightly nicer, but there's less heroes, reworked abilities to the point that some heroes are straight up useless now, they added a way to earn store currency through playing, but that's another half truth, as the amount you earn for thousands of hours isn't even worth a legendary skin.

The newly introduced story mode is paid, it's not free and it's mostly cutscenes and lackluster gameplay. The actual interesting PVE mode was removed to focus on more skins and battlepasses well into it's development, and seemingly with how the story mode is... they only kept it as it was easy to make and could get easy money. And that the big takeaway with all this, money, that's all they care about with this game. Don't give them the light of day, and don't waste your own time.

There's more issues relating to the real world practices of blizzard, but these reasons alone are more than enough reason to not play the game

I wish Steam had a 'mixed' option for reviews.

The game definitely has issues, and they should not be ignored. 

That being said, the game itself can still be fun, especially with friends. The only content you are locked out of as a F2P player is the PVE content (which I agree is a shell of what it was promised to be and don't recommend at all).

As a PVP game, which is the majority of content, the game is still fun, and I would recommend. Just don't support the bullshit, no one is forcing you to buy a skin or the PVE.  As long as you only want to play the PvP, it's an easy recommend from me.

If you really want to leave a negative review for the BS PVE, go to the specific page for the PVE bundle instead and leave it there.

A small premise: I am mostly a casual gamer, not interested in the competitive side of games, nor do I care about skins and other features that don't directly affect the gameplay (I played hatless for a long time even in tf2 :) ). 

The core game itself is solid, it's basically the original OW but 5v5 - if you don't know it's basically a FPS shooter with heroes, each of which has its own abilities and an ultimate. This is in practice a weaboo rebranding of the classic "choose your weapon" and "choose your powers" mechanic. Like all multiplayer games, it's way more enjoyable with friends, especially considering the large amount of toxic basement dwellers infesting this game :-)

From a graphical perspective OW2 is not particularly innovative but at least looks pretty and doesn't require a very powerful PC to run, something which is honestly quite underrated today. 
From a sonic point of view, OW2 is great, but while the OST contains mostly forgettable (but still well-made!) pieces, the sound design steals the show.

Now, let's talk about the elephant in the room, which is also the reason behind the (currently) very angry reviews: the F2P model. Currently a battle pass (around â‚¬10) is required to unlock new heroes in an easy and painless way AND to be able to play the latest hero; heroes introduced in previous seasons can be unlocked without paying by winning around 30 matches for each (and some other easy challenges in the practice range), and the one introduced in the current season by getting to ~50 levels in the FREE battle pass. This is not something I like but it's not as unreasonable as others say (you don't pay with your money, you pay with your time).
I don't care about the PVE, but some have legit concerns about that too.
Of course, compared to the previous one-off payment for OW1 this is a downgrade, but not worthy of a (currently) "10% total positive reviews", especially considering much more infamous free to play models in other games.
